p: The Kamchatka peninsula is situated in northeastern Russia and spans a region of approximately 400 by 1200 km ( Figure 2). The region contains 30 active volcanoes and approximately 270 hydrothermal fields. The most intensive hydrothermal activity traces a narrow zone along the axis of deep faults that cross the volcanic belts of eastern and central Kamchatka, with a breadth ranging from 30 to 50 kilometers. Over the years, hydrothermal processes in this area have attracted the attention of a number of Russian scientists [ 2, 3, 4, 5, 6].
